title._content: Saint Christopher and the Infant Christ TheMET(8)

description._content: Week 3 Problem is, once you’ve done hands and feet…now you have to do knees (661-665) Domenico Ghirlandaio ( Domenico Bigordi) Italian, Florence 1448/49—1494 Florence Saint Christopher and the Infant Christ , ca. 1472-75 Fresco Inscribed (on globe): ASIA / AFRIHA / [E]VROPA This mural is an early work by the Florentine artist Ghirlandaio, who was renowned as a fresco painter and the head of an important workshop where the young Michelangelo trained. In the fresco technique, pigments mixed with water are applied directly on a fresh ( or fresco) plaster wall. As the plaster sets, a chemical reaction occurs whereby the pigment particles become locked into the wall, giving the work great durability. The imposing figure of Saint Christopher, with wind –blown garments, wades through the water carrying the Christ Child on his shoulders. His identity unknown, the Christ Child asked Christopher ( meaning “Christ-bearer”) to help him cross the river, as he had done for others. As he grew increasingly heavy, the Christ Child revealed himself to Christopher and informed him that he was bearing the weight of the world and its creator on his shoulders. Images of Saint Christopher, the patron saint of travelers, were often placed near the doorways of churches. This fresco may have adorned a chapel in the Michelozzi villa in Florence. This work is on generous loan from the Department of European Paintings. Gift of Cornelius Vanderbilt, 1880 ( 80.3.674) From the placard: Metropolitan Museum of Art . www.metmuseum.org/ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domenico_Ghirlandaio www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_object... womeninrenaissanceart.wikispaces.com/Birth+of+the+Virgin
